marklogic.body:
I came to break the news about Keith Boomerang being canned by another Sorosy outlet, but I see Jack beat me to the Â punch.

Ruined my day.

On the flip side, where's the concern troll deprimusjon? He hoo kept wailing about how Limbaugh was taking it on the chin and stomped into Excellence in Broadcasting sawdust.

Mediaite and the Wash Post seem to think it turned out to be much adieu over nothing:

How do you call up someone's activity log without first finding an old post of theirs? I want to be the one bearing the bad tidings to Baghdad deprimusjon.

Mainly because I have the gift of delicateness (delicacy?). But you know that.

Washington PostÂ Declares Rush Limbaugh Boycott Nearly Over, Failed

byÂ Noah RothmanÂ | 8:56 am, March 29th, 2012

Â»The effort to boycott advertisers on theÂ Rush LimbaughÂ radio program appears to be drawing to a close, according to theÂ Washington Post. Limbaugh had sparked the ire of a number of progressive groups for his multi-day attacks onÂ Sandra FlukeÂ for advocating Congress mandate copay-less insurance coverage of birth control and contraceptives. On Wednesday, WaPoâ€™sÂ Paul FarhiÂ declared the boycott on Limbaughâ€™s advertisers was largely a failure.

â€œThe dark clouds hanging over Rush Limbaugh appear to be lifting,â€ writes Farhi. â€œOn Monday, the 600 or so radio stations that air Limbaughâ€™s program were told by his syndicator, Premiere Radio Networks, to resume running â€œbarterâ€ ads during his program.â€ Clear Channel, Premierâ€™s parent network, had previously suspended barter ads while Limbaugh was in the news.

The boycott was initially successful, forcing fewer than five of Limbaughâ€™s national advertisers to cease funding the program. However, boycott organizers who claimed that over 100 advertisers dropped Limbaughâ€™s program were stretching the truth as â€œsome of these companies werenâ€™t regular Limbaugh sponsors in the first place.â€ Most of the advertisers who opted to drop their ads from Limbaughâ€™s program were only airing those Spots in regional markets.

At the height of the controversy, Limbaugh lost two small syndicated stations in Western Massachusetts and Hawaii. All of the major markets that carry Limbaughâ€™s program opted to weather the storm â€“ now it seems the clouds are clearing.

The organizers of the boycott effort are not done yet. The liberal group MoveOn org has organized a petition with SignOn org which asks for signatures to force Limbaughâ€™s program Off his 180 stations. But with interest in the month-old scandal waning, the likelihood of further success in the â€œStop Rushâ€ is in doubt.

h/tÂ Washington Post, viaÂ Hot Air
